elements.content: The preparation and crystal structures of six new copper(II) compounds of formula [Cu(dppn)2(ClO4)]ClO4 (1), [Cu2(dppn)(OH)(ClO4)3(H2O)3]·H2O (2), [Cu2(dppn)2(H2O)2](ClO4)4 (3), [Cu2(dppn)2(ClO4)4] (4), {[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4]·H2O/[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4(H2O)]} n (5) and {[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(dca)3]·H2O} n (6) [dppn = 3,6-bis(2′-pyridyl)pyridazine and dca = dicyanamide] are reported. 1 is a mononuclear complex where two bidentate dppn molecules and a monodentate perchlorate build an intermediate square pyramidal/trigonal bipyramidal (sp/tbp) five-coordinate environment around the copper(II) ion, the overall positive charge being balanced by a free perchlorate anion. 2–4 are dinuclear complexes with either one (2) or two bis-bidentate dppn ligands (3, 4) and a single hydroxo bridge (2). One (2) or two water molecules (3) and three (2) or four perchlorate groups (4) complete the metal coordination sphere, describing elongated octahedral (2 and 4) or intermediate sp/tbp environments (3). Free perchlorate anions neutralize the positive charge of the dicopper(II) unit in 3. 3 and 4 are noteworthy because 1:1 Cu(II)-dppn complexes have never been reported. The simultaneous use of dppn and potentially bridging coligands such as azide and dca led to the chain compounds 5 and 6. Two forms, {[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4]·H2O} n (5A) and {[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4(H2O)]} n (5B), were noted to coexist in the crystals of complex 5, sharing a common [Cu2(dppn)(N3)4] dicopper(II) fragment. 5A consists of a step-like one-dimensional polymer in which the dinuclear entities are linked through single end-to-end azido bridges, while a supramolecular one-dimensional motif is present in 5B, where the Cu–(μ1,3-N3)–Cu link is replaced by a Cu–Ow···(N3)–Cu hydrogen-bonding interaction. Similarly, [Cu2(dppn)(μ-OH)(dca)2] dicopper(II) fragments in 6 are connected via single μ1,5-dca bridges. However an intrachain hydrogen bond is also present in this case, contributing to define a ladder-like motif instead. The variable-temperature magnetic study of 2, 3, 5 and 6 reveals the occurrence of very strong antiferromagnetic interactions between the copper(II) ions [2, 3 and 6 being practically diamagnetic at room temperature and J = −598(5) cm–1 for 5; H = −J S A · S B]. The remarkable efficiency of the double (3) and single diazine (2, 5 and 6) and single hydroxo (2 and 6) or end-on azido (5) groups to mediate electronic effects when acting as bridges between the copper(II) ions [values of the copper–copper separation of 3.346(1) (2), 3.785(2) (3), 3.469(1) (5) and 3.368(1) Å (6)] accounts for the strong magnetic couplings observed in these compounds.

elements.content: The preparation, crystal structure, and magnetic properties of a series of complexes obtained from the reaction of aqueous solutions of copper(II) perchlorate with 3,6-bis(2′-pyridyl)pyridazine (dppn) and in the absence/presence of potentially bridging coligands, namely, [Cu(dppn)2(ClO4)]ClO4 (1), [Cu2(dppn)(OH)(ClO4)3(H2O)3]·H2O (2), [Cu2(dppn)2(H2O)2]4(ClO4)2 (3), [Cu2(dppn)2(ClO4)4] (4), {[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4]·H2O/[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4(H2O)]} n (5) and {[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(dca)3]·H2O} n (6) are described. The dinuclear compounds 3 and 4 are especially noteworthy because of the occurrence of [Cu2(dppn)2]4+ that was unprecedented in the literature. 3 and 4 only differ by the absence/presence of axially coordinated perchlorate ions, and most likely, an equilibrium between these two forms exists in solution. The double diazine (3), single diazine/hydroxo (2 and 6) and single diazine/end-on azido bridges (5) are very efficient mediators of magnetic interactions between the copper(II) ions that they connect.
elements.clean_text: The preparation, crystal structure, and magnetic properties of a series of complexes obtained from the reaction of aqueous solutions of copper(II) perchlorate with 3,6-bis(2'-pyridyl)pyridazine (dppn) and in the absence/presence of potentially bridging coligands, namely, [Cu(dppn)2(ClO4)]ClO4 (1), [Cu2(dppn)(OH)(ClO4)3(H2O)3]⋅H2O (2), [Cu2(dppn)2(H2O)2]4(ClO4)2 (3), [Cu2(dppn)2(ClO4)4] (4), {[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4]⋅H2O/[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4(H2O)]} n  (5) and {[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(dca)3]⋅H2O} n  (6) are described. The dinuclear compounds 3 and 4 are especially noteworthy because of the occurrence of [Cu2(dppn)2]4+ that was unprecedented in the literature. 3 and 4 only differ by the absence/presence of axially coordinated perchlorate ions, and most likely, an equilibrium between these two forms exists in solution. The double diazine (3), single diazine/hydroxo (2 and 6) and single diazine/end-on azido bridges (5) are very efficient mediators of magnetic interactions between the copper(II) ions that they connect.

elements.content: Crystal engineering of coordination polymers is attracting continuous attention, mainly due to the innovative possibilities offered by the rational design of new materials showing useful and intriguing properties. The final architecture of the resulting network can be in principle tuned by subtle changes in the metal environment and/or synthetic procedures. The selection of the metal ions, ligands/coligands and preparative routes makes possible to obtain either discrete entities or polymeric species, as well as to establish a wide variety of geometrical arrangements around the metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystal engineering of coordination polymers is attracting continuous attention, mainly due to the innovative possibilities offered by the rational design of new materials showing useful and intriguing properties. The final architecture of the resulting network can be in principle tuned by subtle changes in the metal environment and/or synthetic procedures. The selection of the metal ions, ligands/coligands and preparative routes makes possible to obtain either discrete entities or polymeric species, as well as to establish a wide variety of geometrical arrangements around the metal ions.

elements.content: In this research field, great efforts have been devoted to the study of metal complexes with bis-bidentate diazine type ligands. It has been established that the N2 diazine linkages in open-chain systems containing N–N single bonds are rather flexible and can lead to quite different coordination geometries and network topologies, as a result of the ability of the ligand to twist around the N–N linkage. On the contrary, the inclusion of the N2 diazine moiety in heterocyclic rings results in a poorer coordination flexibility caused by the rigidity of the aromatic N–N linkage. In particular, pyridazine-based ligands have been noted to favor the formation of mononuclear or discrete polynuclear complexes, even in the presence of potentially bridging coligands. Only a few exceptions are known to defy this general rule.
elements.clean_text: In this research field, great efforts have been devoted to the study of metal complexes with bis-bidentate diazine type ligands. On the contrary, the inclusion of the N2 diazine moiety in heterocyclic rings results in a poorer coordination flexibility caused by the rigidity of the aromatic N-N linkage. In particular, pyridazine-based ligands have been noted to favor the formation of mononuclear or discrete polynuclear complexes, even in the presence of potentially bridging coligands. Only a few exceptions are known to defy this general rule.

elements.content: In the present study, we explored the possibility of synthesizing new Cu(II)-containing polymeric coordination compounds based on dppn [dppn = 3,6-bis(2′-pyridyl)pyridazine] ligand. The versatile coordination properties of the copper(II) ion could be helpful in eluding the geometrical restraint imposed by the rigidity of the ligand and, in principle, a wide variety of geometrical arrangements and networks topologies can be expected.
elements.clean_text: In the present study, we explored the possibility of synthesizing new Cu(II)-containing polymeric coordination compounds based on dppn [dppn = 3,6-bis(2'-pyridyl)pyridazine] ligand. The versatile coordination properties of the copper(II) ion could be helpful in eluding the geometrical restraint imposed by the rigidity of the ligand and, in principle, a wide variety of geometrical arrangements and networks topologies can be expected.

elements.content: Different counterions with opposite coordinative properties (barely coordinating perchlorate and potentially bridging azide and dicyanamide anions) were selected with the double aim of investigating the coordinative ability of dppn toward the copper(II) ion in the absence of competitive ligands and exploring the possibility of obtaining extended coordination polymers when potentially bridging counterions are present.

elements.content: We report herein the preparation, crystal structure and magnetic properties of a series of complexes obtained from the reaction of aqueous solutions of copper(II) perchlorate with 3,6-bis(2′-pyridyl)pyridazine (dppn). Four new discrete complexes of formulas [Cu(dppn)2(ClO4)]ClO4 (1), [Cu2(dppn)­(OH)­(ClO4)3­(H2O)3]­·H2O (2), [Cu2(dppn)2­(H2O)2]4­(ClO4)2 (3) and [Cu2(dppn)2­(ClO4)4] (4) were prepared by simply varying the metal-to-ligand molar ratio [1:2 (1), 2:1 (2) and 2:2 (3 and 4)], while the simultaneous use of azide or dicyanamide (dca) anions allowed the assembly of the one-dimensional (1D) polymers {[Cu2(dppn)­(N3)4]­·H2O/[Cu2(dppn)­(N3)4­(H2O)]} n (5) and {[Cu2(dppn)­(OH)­(dca)3]­·H2O} n (6).

Four new discrete complexes of formulas [Cu(dppn)2(ClO4)]ClO4 (1), [Cu2(dppn)(OH)(ClO4)3(H2O)3]⋅H2O (2), [Cu2(dppn)2(H2O)2]4(ClO4)2 (3) and [Cu2(dppn)2(ClO4)4] (4) were prepared by simply varying the metal-to-ligand molar ratio [1:2 (1), 2:1 (2) and 2:2 (3 and 4)], while the simultaneous use of azide or dicyanamide (dca) anions allowed the assembly of the one-dimensional (1D) polymers {[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4]⋅H2O/[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4(H2O)]} n  (5) and {[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(dca)3]⋅H2O} n  (6).

elements.content: All chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used as received without further purification. dppn was prepared according to a previously reported procedure. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed by the Microanalytical Service at the Università della Calabria.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used as received without further purification. dppn was prepared according to a previously reported procedure. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed by the Microanalytical Service at the Università della Calabria.

elements.content:
Caution! Perchlorate and azide salts are potentially explosive. Only small amounts of the materials should be prepared and handled with care.

[Cu(dppn)<sub>2</sub>(ClO<sub>4</sub>)]ClO<sub>4</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

This compound was obtained by reaction of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O and dppn in a 1:2 molar ratio. X-ray quality crystals of 1 as sky blue plates were obtained after a few days by slow diffusion in a test tube of an aqueous solution of the copper(II) salt into an ethanolic solution of the dppn ligand. The yield was practically quantitative. Anal. Calcd for C28H20Cl2CuN8O8 (1): C, 46.01; H, 2.76; N, 15.33. Found: C, 45.84; H, 2.68; N, 15.29%.

Syntheses

[Cu(dppn)2(ClO4)]ClO4 (1)

X-ray quality crystals of 1 as sky blue plates were obtained after a few days by slow diffusion in a test tube of an aqueous solution of the copper(II) salt into an ethanolic solution of the dppn ligand. The yield was practically quantitative. Anal. Calcd for C28H20Cl2CuN8O8 (1): C, 46.01; H, 2.76; N, 15.33. Found: C, 45.84; H, 2.68; N, 15.29%.

elements.content: X-ray quality crystals of 2 were obtained as green needles from a concentrated solution containing 0.2 mmol of the copper(II) salt dissolved in water and 0.1 mmol of dppn dissolved in ethanol. Yield: ca. 90%. Anal. Calcd for C14H19Cl3Cu2N4O17 (2): C, 22.46; H, 2.56; N, 7.48. Found: C, 22.30; H, 2.49; N, 7.36%.
elements.clean_text:
[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(ClO4)3(H2O)3]⋅H2O (2)

X-ray quality crystals of 2 were obtained as green needles from a concentrated solution containing 0.2 mmol of the copper(II) salt dissolved in water and 0.1 mmol of dppn dissolved in ethanol. Yield: ca. 90%. Anal. Calcd for C14H19Cl3Cu2N4O17 (2): C, 22.46; H, 2.56; N, 7.48. Found: C, 22.30; H, 2.49; N, 7.36%.

elements.content: Compound 3 separated as a deep green crystalline solid by adding an aqueous solution of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol) to an ethanolic solution of the dppn ligand (0.1 mmol). Green rhombuses of 3 suitable for X-ray structural analysis were grown by slow diffusion in a H-shaped tube of the aqueous solution of the copper(II) salt in one arm and the ethanolic solution of the ligand in the other one. An ethanol/water mixture (1:1 v/v) was used to fill the H-tube. A few blue rhombuses of 4 appeared in the same tube after one month, when the diffusion was complete at room temperature. Crystals of 3 (main product) and 4 (traces) were collected together and separated manually. Yield of 3: ca. 55%. Anal. Calcd for C14H12Cl2CuN4O9 (3): C, 32.67; H, 2.35; N, 10.88. Found: C, 32.40; H, 2.40; N, 10.57%. The composition of 4 was established by crystallographic analysis.

elements.content: Compounds 5 and 6 were both obtained as dark microcrystalline solids by reaction of Cu(ClO4)2 · 6H2O, dppn and NaN3 (5) or Na(dca) (6) in a 2:1:4 copper(II):dppn:N3/dca molar ratio. Single crystals as brown (5) or deep green (6) parallelepipeds were grown by slow diffusion in a H-shaped tube of an aqueous solution of the copper(II) salt in one arm and an ethanolic solution containing a mixture of dppn and azide (5) or dicyanamide (6) salts in the other one. An ethanol/water mixture (1:1 v/v) was used to fill the H-tube. The diffusion was completed after one month. Yield: ca. 65 (5) and 70% (6). Anal. Calcd for C14H12Cu2N16O (5): C, 30.71; H, 2.21; N, 40.93. Found: C, 30.16; H, 2.18; N, 41.12%. Anal. Calcd for C20H13Cu2N13O2 (6): C, 40.40; H, 2.20; N, 30.63. Found: C, 39.89; H, 2.16; N, 30.23%.

Compounds 5 and 6 were both obtained as dark microcrystalline solids by reaction of Cu(ClO4)2 ⋅ 6H2O, dppn and NaN3 (5) or Na(dca) (6) in a 2:1:4 copper(II):dppn:N3/dca molar ratio. Single crystals as brown (5) or deep green (6) parallelepipeds were grown by slow diffusion in a H-shaped tube of an aqueous solution of the copper(II) salt in one arm and an ethanolic solution containing a mixture of dppn and azide (5) or dicyanamide (6) salts in the other one. An ethanol/water mixture (1:1 v/v) was used to fill the H-tube. The diffusion was completed after one month. Yield: ca. 65 (5) and 70% (6). Anal. Calcd for C14H12Cu2N16O (5): C, 30.71; H, 2.21; N, 40.93. Found: C, 30.16; H, 2.18; N, 41.12%. Anal. Calcd for C20H13Cu2N13O2 (6): C, 40.40; H, 2.20; N, 30.63. Found: C, 39.89; H, 2.16; N, 30.23%.

elements.content: Variable temperature (1.9–300 K) magnetic susceptibility measurements on polycrystalline samples of 2, 3, 5 and 6 were carried out with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer in under an applied magnetic field of 1000 G over the whole temperature range. The device was calibrated with (NH4)2Mn(SO4)2·6H2O. Diamagnetic corrections for the constituent atoms were estimated from Pascal constants as −317 × 10–6 (2), −446 × 10–6 (3), −237 × 10–6 (5) and −268 × 10–6 (6) per two copper(II) ions. A value of 60 × 10–6 cm3 mol–1 was used for the temperature-independent paramagnetism of the copper(II) ion and corrections for the sample holder were also applied.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Techniques

Variable temperature (1.9-300 K) magnetic susceptibility measurements on polycrystalline samples of 2, 3, 5 and 6 were carried out with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer in under an applied magnetic field of 1000 G over the whole temperature range. The device was calibrated with (NH4)2Mn(SO4)2⋅6H2O. Diamagnetic corrections for the constituent atoms were estimated from Pascal constants as -317 × 10-6 (2), -446 × 10-6 (3), -237 × 10-6 (5) and -268 × 10-6 (6) per two copper(II) ions. A value of 60 × 10-6 cm3 mol-1 was used for the temperature-independent paramagnetism of the copper(II) ion and corrections for the sample holder were also applied.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data were collected with a Siemens R3m/V automatic four-circle (1–3 and 5) and a Bruker-Nonius X8APEXII CCD area detector (4 and 6) diffractometers. Graphite-monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) was used. Lorentz-polarization and empirical absorption corrections through the Ψ-scan program were applied to compounds 1–3 and 5. Data of 4 and 6 were processed through the SAINT reduction and SADABS absorption software. A summary of the crystallographic data and structure refinement for 1–6 is given in Table . The structures of 1–6 were solved by direct methods using SHELXS and refined against F 2 on all data by full-matrix least-squares with SHELXL-97 using established methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms on the dppn molecules in 1–6 were set in calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The hydrogen atom of hydroxo bridge in compounds 2 and 6 as well as the coordinated/crystallization water molecules in 2, 3, 5 and 6 [except those on O(4w) in 2] were located on a ΔF map and refined with restraints. The hydrogen atoms on O(4w) in 2 were not defined; two alternative positions were found for one of the hydrogen atoms on O(2w), instead, whose relative occupancies were fixed to 0.5 each for symmetry reasons. One of the two Cu(2)-weakly coordinated perchlorate anions in 2 was found disordered over two sites; the relative occupancies of the two atomic sets were refined freely within SHELXL, while constraining the sum of the occupancies to unity, and they reached values of 0.81:0.19 at convergence. The Cu(1)-apical coordinated azide group [N(14)N(15)N(16)] in 5 was modeled over two sites, N(14A)N(15A)N(16A) and N(14B)N(15B)N(16B), rotated about 150 °C with respect to each other. The water molecule of crystallization [O(1w)] also appeared involved in such disorder, and it was modeled as O(1wA) plus O(1wB). The two “A” and “B” groups of atoms (azide plus water molecule) are mutually exclusive, and they belong to what we describe as compounds 5A or 5B in the main text. The refined values of the relative occupancies of groups A and B in the analyzed crystal are 0.64 and 0.36. The monodentate dca ligand in 6 which is coordinated to Cu(2) in an equatorial position [N(11)C(19)N(12)C(20)N(13)] was found partially disordered. In particular, the central N atom and terminal -CN group [atoms N(12), C(20) and N(13)] could be modeled over three different sites. Again, the relative occupancy of each disorder component was refined freely while constraining the sum of the occupancies to unity; values at convergence were about 0.48:0.42:0.10. All disorders in 2, 5 and 6 were refined using similarity restraints on 1,2- and 1,3-distances and rigid-bond restraints. Similar anisotropic displacement parameters (ADP) were also applied to some of the atoms of the disordered perchlorate anion in 2. The final full-matrix least-squares refinements on F 2, minimizing the function ∑w(|F o| – |F c|)2, reached convergence with the values of the discrepancy indices given in Table . The final geometrical calculations were carried out with the PARST program, whereas the graphical manipulations were performed with the XP utility of the SHELXTL system. CCDC reference numbers 902866–902871 (1–6).

In particular, the central N atom and terminal -CN group [atoms N(12), C(20) and N(13)] could be modeled over three different sites. Again, the relative occupancy of each disorder component was refined freely while constraining the sum of the occupancies to unity; values at convergence were about 0.48:0.42:0.10. All disorders in 2, 5 and 6 were refined using similarity restraints on 1,2- and 1,3-distances and rigid-bond restraints. Similar anisotropic displacement parameters (ADP) were also applied to some of the atoms of the disordered perchlorate anion in 2. The final full-matrix least-squares refinements on F 2, minimizing the function ∑w(|F o| - |F c|)2, reached convergence with the values of the discrepancy indices given in Table . The final geometrical calculations were carried out with the PARST program, whereas the graphical manipulations were performed with the XP utility of the SHELXTL system. CCDC reference numbers 902866-902871 (1-6).

Results and DiscussionDescription of the Structures[Cu(dppn)<sub>2</sub>(ClO<sub>4</sub>)]ClO<sub>4</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

The crystal structure of 1 is built up of mononuclear [Cu(dppn)2(ClO4)]+ cations (CuN4O chromophore) and uncoordinated perclorate anions (Figure ). The free perchlorate anion displays anion···π interactions through three of its four oxygen atoms [O(7), O(8) and O(5)] with the N(2)/N(3) and N(5)/N(7)-pyridazine and N(1)-pyridyl rings respectively, from the two dppn ligands (Figure ). The value of the centroid···O distance and that of the angle of the centroid···O axis to the plane are 3.26(1) Å and 26.6(1)° [N(2)–/N(3)···O(7)], 3.56(1) Å and 39.6(1)° [N(6)/N(7)···O(8)] and 3.51(1) Å and 23.5(1)° [N(1)···O(5)]. This type of noncovalent supramolecular interactions involving anions and aromatic heterocyclic nitrogen systems is a subject of increasing interest from both theoretical and experimental points of view because of their relevance in chemistry and structural biology and also because of their potential role in the design of receptors of anions. Each copper(II) ion in 1 is five-coordinate with four nitrogen atoms from two bidentate dppn ligands [N(1), N(2), N(5) and N(6)] and one perchlorate-oxygen [O(5)] building a metal surrounding which is intermediate between a square pyramid (SP) and a trigonal bipyramid (TBP), as indicated by a value of the trigonality parameter (τ) of 0.49 [τ = 1 (trigonal bipyramid) and 0 (square pyramid) respectively, according to the Addison et al. definition]. In this sense, the structure of the mononuclear unit in 1 is a bit different from that found in the parent compound [Cu(dppn)2Cl]Cl·5H2O (1a), where the five-coordinate copper(II) environment is closer to a trigonal bipyramid [τ = 0.88] obviously due to the reduced geometrical constraints of the noncoordinated chloride with respect to the bulkier free perchlorate in 1. As shown in Figure , two crystallographically independent dppn molecules act as chelating bidentate ligands [bite angles of 81.1(1) and 80.1(1)°] toward a copper(II) ion from the cationic entity, the two noncoordinating N atoms (one from a pyridyl ring and the other one from the pyridazine one) being in trans to each other.

Results and Discussion

Description of the Structures

[Cu(dppn)2(ClO4)]ClO4 (1)

The crystal structure of 1 is built up of mononuclear [Cu(dppn)2(ClO4)]+ cations (CuN4O chromophore) and uncoordinated perclorate anions (Figure ). The free perchlorate anion displays anion⋅⋅⋅π interactions through three of its four oxygen atoms [O(7), O(8) and O(5)] with the N(2)/N(3) and N(5)/N(7)-pyridazine and N(1)-pyridyl rings respectively, from the two dppn ligands (Figure ). The value of the centroid⋅⋅⋅O distance and that of the angle of the centroid⋅⋅⋅O axis to the plane are 3.26(1) Å and 26.6(1)° [N(2)-/N(3)⋅⋅⋅O(7)], 3.56(1) Å and 39.6(1)° [N(6)/N(7)⋅⋅⋅O(8)] and 3.51(1) Å and 23.5(1)° [N(1)⋅⋅⋅O(5)]. This type of noncovalent supramolecular interactions involving anions and aromatic heterocyclic nitrogen systems is a subject of increasing interest from both theoretical and experimental points of view because of their relevance in chemistry and structural biology and also because of their potential role in the design of receptors of anions. Each copper(II) ion in 1 is five-coordinate with four nitrogen atoms from two bidentate dppn ligands [N(1), N(2), N(5) and N(6)] and one perchlorate-oxygen [O(5)] building a metal surrounding which is intermediate between a square pyramid (SP) and a trigonal bipyramid (TBP), as indicated by a value of the trigonality parameter (τ) of 0.49 [τ = 1 (trigonal bipyramid) and 0 (square pyramid) respectively, according to the Addison et al. definition]. In this sense, the structure of the mononuclear unit in 1 is a bit different from that found in the parent compound [Cu(dppn)2Cl]Cl⋅5H2O (1a), where the five-coordinate copper(II) environment is closer to a trigonal bipyramid [τ = 0.88] obviously due to the reduced geometrical constraints of the noncoordinated chloride with respect to the bulkier free perchlorate in 1. As shown in Figure , two crystallographically independent dppn molecules act as chelating bidentate ligands [bite angles of 81.1(1) and 80.1(1)°] toward a copper(II) ion from the cationic entity, the two noncoordinating N atoms (one from a pyridyl ring and the other one from the pyridazine one) being in trans to each other.

elements.content: The individual pyridyl and pyridazine rings of both molecules are practically planar [mean deviation from planarity ranging from 0.001(2) to 0.018(2) Å], but the ligand as a whole is a bit far from being planar. The two ligands form a dihedral angle of ca. 48°, so that the uncoordinated perchlorate anion can be accommodated between them and establish interactions with the aromatic rings, as indicated above. The bond distances and angles of the dppn ligands in 1 agree with those found in the free dppn molecule and in other copper(II) complexes containing the bidentate dppn ligand.

elements.content: Compound 2 results from the reaction of the copper(II) salt and the dppn ligand in a 2:1 metal to ligand molar ratio. Its structure consists of dicopper(II) units containing two crystallographically independent copper(II) ions [Cu(1) and Cu(2)] simultaneously bridged by the N(2)–N(3) pyridazine nitrogens from the dppn ligand and an hydroxo group. This double bridge has been previously observed in two other dinuclear copper(II) complexes of formulas [Cu2(dppn)(OH)Cl3(H2O)] and [Cu2(dppn)(OH)(NO3)Cl2(H2O)] as well as in the chain compounds [Cu2(dppn)(OH)Br3] n and {[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(tcm)2]·tcm} n . Coordinated water molecules and perchlorate anions, one of which was found to be disordered and could be modeled as two distinct sets of atoms, [Cl(2)O(6)O(7)O(8)O(9)] and [Cl(2A)O(6A)O(7A)O(8A)O(9A)], complete the coordination sphere at the copper atoms in 2 (Figure ).

[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(ClO4)3(H2O)3]⋅H2O (2)

Compound 2 results from the reaction of the copper(II) salt and the dppn ligand in a 2:1 metal to ligand molar ratio. Its structure consists of dicopper(II) units containing two crystallographically independent copper(II) ions [Cu(1) and Cu(2)] simultaneously bridged by the N(2)-N(3) pyridazine nitrogens from the dppn ligand and an hydroxo group. This double bridge has been previously observed in two other dinuclear copper(II) complexes of formulas [Cu2(dppn)(OH)Cl3(H2O)] and [Cu2(dppn)(OH)(NO3)Cl2(H2O)] as well as in the chain compounds [Cu2(dppn)(OH)Br3] n   and {[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(tcm)2]⋅tcm} n . Coordinated water molecules and perchlorate anions, one of which was found to be disordered and could be modeled as two distinct sets of atoms, [Cl(2)O(6)O(7)O(8)O(9)] and [Cl(2A)O(6A)O(7A)O(8A)O(9A)], complete the coordination sphere at the copper atoms in 2 (Figure ).

elements.content: Both copper(II) ions in 2 are in elongated octahedral environments. Two nitrogen atoms from the dppn ligand [N(1)–N(2) at Cu(1) and N(3)–N(4) at Cu(2)], an oxygen atom of the hydroxo group [O(1)] and an oxygen atom of a coordinated water molecule [O(2w) and O(3w) at Cu(1) and Cu(2), respectively] constitute the equatorial planes. The axial positions are occupied by an oxygen atom of a water molecule [O(2w)] and an oxygen atom of a weakly coordinated perchlorate ion [O(2)] at Cu(1) and by two oxygen atoms of two weakly coordinated perchlorate ion [O(6)/O(9A) and O(10)] at Cu(2). The metal surroundings together with the atom numbering are shown in Figure .

The axial positions are occupied by an oxygen atom of a water molecule [O(2w)] and an oxygen atom of a weakly coordinated perchlorate ion [O(2)] at Cu(1) and by two oxygen atoms of two weakly coordinated perchlorate ion [O(6)/O(9A) and O(10)] at Cu(2). The metal surroundings together with the atom numbering are shown in Figure .

elements.content: The values of the copper–copper separation through the hydroxo bridge and that of the angle at the bridgehead oxygen (τ) are 3.346(1) Å and 120.7(1)°, respectively. The dppn ligand is somewhat bent, the value of the dihedral angle between the N(4)-pyridyl ring and the mean plane comprising the pyridazine and the other pyridyl ring is 13.1(1)°. This significant bending of the dppn is likely favored by a weak anion-π type interaction between one of the two Cu(2)-weakly coordinated perchlorate anions and the N(4)-pyridyl ring [3.23(1) Å and 21.2(1)° for the centroid···O(13) distance and angle of the centroid···O(13) axis to the plane, respectively]. Bis-dinuclear supramolecular assemblies are formed through hydrogen bonding interactions involving the hydroxo group, O(3w) and the disordered perchlorate anion [2.860(5)/2.867(13) and 2.802(4) Å for O(1)···O(9a)/O(1)···O(9Aa) and O(3w)···O(1a), respectively; symmetry code: (a) = −x, −y + 2, −z] (Figure a). Hydrogen bonds between symmetry-related O(2w) water molecules [2.996(7) Å for O(2w)···O(2wb); symmetry code: (b) = −x + 1, −y + 2, −z] contribute to assemble these bis-dinuclear entities in supramolecular 1D tapes running along the crystallographic a axis. As shown in Figure b, an occupancy of 0.5 only must be attributed to the hydrogen atom responsible for this particular dimer–dimer interaction [H(4wA)], for symmetry reasons; a possible alternative position for H(4w), i.e., H(4wB), located from the density map as described earlier, is also shown. This motif is further stabilized by an interaction between O(1w) and a perchlorate anion [O(1w)···O(12b) = 2.733(4) Å].

Although the hydrogen atoms from O(4w) could not be located, plausible interactions are O(3w)···O(4w) = 2.695(4) Å (as acceptor) and O(4w)···(O3a) = 2.902(4), O(4w)···(O7) = 3.059(11) or O(4w)···(O7a) = 2.91(5) (as donor). A three-dimensional supramolecular structure is achieved for 2 through additional hydrogen bonds established by the O(1w) water molecule [O(1w)···O(5c) = 2.779(4) Å; symmetry code: (c) = −x, y + 3, −z], which hold together the supramolecular 1D tapes in the crystallographic ab plane, whereas offset π–π stacking interactions involving two rings of the dppn ligand [pyridazine and N(1)-pyridyl] occur in the crystallographic c direction [average stacking distance 3.17(1)Å].

elements.content: Compounds 3 and 4 result from the reaction of the copper(II) salt and the dppn ligand in a 2:2 metal to ligand molar ratio. Both structures contain dicopper(II) units where double pyridazine moieties from the two dppn ligands act as bridges between the two crystallographically equivalent copper(II) ions. A coordinated water molecule complete the coordination sphere at each copper(II) ion in 3, the electroneutrality being ensured by free perchlorate anions (Figure ). In the case of 4, the perchlorate anions act as monodentate ligands toward the copper(II) ions giving rise to neutral entities (Figure ).

elements.content: The five-coordinate environment at each copper(II) ion in 3 is intermediate between square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal as in 1, the value of the trigonality parameter τ being 0.48 in this case. Each copper(II) ion in 4 is six-coordinate in an elongated octahedral surrounding with two pyridazine and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two dppn ligands in the equatorial positions plus two perchlorate-oxygens occupying the axial ones.

elements.content: In both compounds, the two pyridyl and the pyridazine rings of the dppn ligand are practically planar [mean deviation from planarity being 0.012(4), 0.017(2) and 0.017(3) Å (3) and 0015(2), 0.021(2) and 0.024(2) Å (4) for the three rings respectively], but twisted with respect to each other, with angles of 13.5(2) and 18.4(2)° (3) and 10.4(1) and 6.8(1)° (4) between each pyridyl ring and the pyridazine fragment, and 31.9(2) (3) and 14.7(1)° (4) between the two pyridyl rings. The values of the dihedral angle between the pyridazine rings of the two coordinated dppn ligands are 44.7(2) (3) and 33.2(1)° (4), producing a butterfly shape for the dinuclear complexes. The geometrical constraints between the two dppn ligands in the unusual dicopper(II) unit of 3 and 4 preclude a coplanar arrangement of the two dppn molecules. This lack of coplanarity relieves the sterical hindrance between opposite pyridyl hydrogen atoms and makes it possible for such complexes to exist. Although a similar coordination geometry can be found in a few bis-(4-substituted-dppn) silver(I) dimers, they do not possess a distinct butterfly shape similar to that observed in 3 and 4. In fact, in those cases the substituent in the 4-position of the pyridazine ring induces quite a different ligand distortion, the pyridazine ring being forced significantly out of the plane containing the two adjacent pyridyl rings, while the lack of sterical hindrance between cofacial hydrogen atoms must be mainly attributed to longer metal-Ndppn bond interactions in the case of silver(I) with respect to copper(II).

elements.content: The values of the copper···copper separation through the bis-pyridazine bridge are 3.785(2) (3) and 3.708(1) Å (4). Hydrogen bonds between the coordinated water molecules and the perchlorate ions [3.006(6) and 2.956(8) Å for O(1w)···O(2) and O(1w)···O(8), respectively] together with very weak contacts between the copper centers and the perchlorate ions [Cu(1)···O(1b) 3.09(1) Å; symmetry code: (b) = x, 1 + y, z] and anion-π interactions involving the perchlorate-oxygen O(5) and the N(4)-containing pyridyl ring [3.34(1) Å and 28.3(1)° for the centroid···O(5) distance and the angle of the centroid···O(5) axis to the plane, respectively] give rise to a supramolecular 1D motif in 3 which grows along the crystallographic b axis (see Figure b).

elements.content: Two forms, {[Cu2(dppn)(μ1,1-N3)(μ*1,1-N3)2(μ1,3-N3)]·H2O} n (5A) and {[Cu2(dppn)(μ1,1-N3)(μ*1,1-N3)2(N3)(H2O)]} n (5B) systematically coexist in the crystals of compound 5. Both have in common the presence of dicopper(II) units where the two crystallographically independent metal centers [Cu(1) and Cu(2)] are simultaneously bridged by the pyridazinic moiety of the organic ligand and an end-on azide group, denoted as μ1,1-N3 in the chemical formula. The presence of two pseudo-terminal azide groups (referred to as μ*1,1-N3) is also observed in both forms, which ultimately adopt an out-of-plane end-on bridging mode with the weaker axial Cu–N bonds in the range 2.7–3 Å (vide infra). A fourth azide group and the water molecule play quite different structural roles in the two forms, however. They have been labeled as O(1wA) and N(14A)N(15A)N(16A) in 5A and O(1wB) and N(14B)N(15B)N(16B) in 5B (Figure ).

Both have in common the presence of dicopper(II) units where the two crystallographically independent metal centers [Cu(1) and Cu(2)] are simultaneously bridged by the pyridazinic moiety of the organic ligand and an end-on azide group, denoted as μ1,1-N3 in the chemical formula. The presence of two pseudo-terminal azide groups (referred to as μ*1,1-N3) is also observed in both forms, which ultimately adopt an out-of-plane end-on bridging mode with the weaker axial Cu-N bonds in the range 2.7-3 Å (vide infra). A fourth azide group and the water molecule play quite different structural roles in the two forms, however. They have been labeled as O(1wA) and N(14A)N(15A)N(16A) in 5A and O(1wB) and N(14B)N(15B)N(16B) in 5B (Figure ).

elements.content: A view of the dinuclear entities in 5 in both the A (a) and B (b) forms showing the atom numbering and hydrogen bonds (dashed lines). Thermal ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level.

elements.content: The azide group in 5A connects axial positions of copper(II) ions from adjacent dinuclear entities, adopting the end-to-end coordination mode [Cu–N bonds in the range 2.3–2.5 Å] and giving rise to a chain motif, while the water molecule is only involved in hydrogen bonds [O(1wA)···N(14A) = 2.815 Å]. However, the same azide group in 5B is rotated about 150° around the Cu–N bond with respect to its position in 5A, and it only acts as a terminal ligand (N3 in the chemical formula). The water molecule in 5B occupies the axial position of the alternatively azide-connected copper(II) ion, producing this time a supramolecular chain motif (which is reminiscent of that occurring in 5A) through a hydrogen bond with the terminal azide group [2.940 Å for O(1wB)···N(14B)]. Weak Cu–N axial bonds [Cu(2)–N(11a) = 2.791(1) Å, symmetry code: (a) = −x – 1, −y + 1, −z] involving a first pseudoterminal azide are responsible for a ribbon-like motif in both forms A and B (Figure ). An additional, weaker Cu–N contact [Cu(1)–N(8b) = 2.951(1) Å, symmetry code: (b) = −x – 1, −y + 1, −z + 1] involving the second pseudoterminal azide leads to a layered arrangement in both A and B forms. The three-dimensional cohesion is ensured by very weak supramolecular interactions between the in-plane azide groups and the hydrogen atoms from the dppn ligands.

elements.content: If we focus on to the dinuclear units, each copper(II) atom is five-coordinate in a distorted square pyramidal environment being bonded to either five nitrogen atoms [Cu(1) (5A and 5B) and Cu(2) (5B)] or to four nitrogen atoms plus a water molecule [Cu(2) (5B)]. The basal plane at each copper(II) ion is formed by two nitrogen atoms from the dppn ligand [N(1) and N(2) for Cu(1) and N(2) and N(3) for Cu(2)], and other two from the azide ligands [N(8) and N(11) for Cu(1) and Cu(2), respectively, and N(5) in common] in both forms. The copper(II) ions are shifted by 0.192(2) [Cu(1)] and 0.129(1) Å [Cu(2)] from the mean basal plane toward the apical position which is filled by the nitrogen atoms from the μ1,3-azide bridge [N(14A) for Cu(1) and N(16Ac) for Cu(2); symmetry code: (c) = x + 1, y, z] in 5A and by the oxygen atom of the water molecule [O(1wBc) for Cu(2)] and the nitrogen atom of the terminal azide [N(14B) for Cu(1)] in 5B. The two copper(II) ions could be viewed as six-coordinate with a distorted octahedral geometry if one considers the weak Cu–Nazide axial interactions [Cu(1)–N(8b) and Cu(2)–N(11a)].

elements.content: The dppn ligand as a whole is almost planar [main deviation from planarity of ca. 0.04 Å]. The azide groups in 5A and 5B are quasi linear [values in the range 174.2(4)–179.8(4)°], and the intra-azide nitrogen–nitrogen bonds agree with the values observed in the great number of structurally characterized azide-containing copper(II) complexes.

elements.content: The copper–copper separation through the in-plane μ1,1-azide bridge is 3.469(1) Å. The covalent (5A) or supramolecular (5B) step-like chains shown in Figure a,b and built up by either the μ1,3-azide bridge (5A) or the hydrogen bond between the terminally bound azide and coordinated water molecule (5B) run along the crystallographic a axis, the metal–metal separation being 6.456(1) Å [Cu(1c)···Cu(2)]. This value is much larger than the copper–copper separation through the double end-on azide bridge between the Cu(2) atoms [Cu(2)···Cu(2a) = 3.617(1) Å] and single end-on azide between the Cu(1) atoms [Cu(1)···Cu(1b) = 3.785(1) Å].

elements.content: Compound 6 is made up of dicopper(II) units simultaneously bridged by the pyridazine moiety of the organic ligand and an hydroxo group, similar to complex 2. Three coordinated dca anions complete the surroundings of the two crystallographically independent copper(II) ions [Cu(1) and Cu(2)]. Two of these dca groups are monodentate, while the other acts as a μ1,5 bridge, linking one equatorial position at Cu(1) to the apical position at the Cu(2) atom from a symmetry-related dicopper(II) unit (Figure ). A crystallization water molecule is also present in 6.

elements.content: The monodentate and bridging dca ligands in 6 are planar and their bond distances and angles indicate localized single carbon–carbon and triple carbon–nitrogen bonds with the values of the angle at the central nitrogen atom varying in the range 112–122°. The value of the copper–copper separation through the hydroxo bridge and that of the angle at the bridgehead oxygen (θ) are 3.368(1) Å and 115.8(1)°, respectively, values that are somewhat shorter than those observed in 2, but in agreement with those reported previously for related dinuclear complexes.

elements.content: The present study describes the preparation, crystal structure and magnetic properties of a series of complexes obtained from the reaction of aqueous solutions of copper(II) perchlorate with 3,6-bis(2′-pyridyl)pyridazine (dppn) (1–4) and sodium azide (5) or dicyanamide (6).
elements.clean_text:
Comments on the Formation of 1-6 

The present study describes the preparation, crystal structure and magnetic properties of a series of complexes obtained from the reaction of aqueous solutions of copper(II) perchlorate with 3,6-bis(2'-pyridyl)pyridazine (dppn) (1-4) and sodium azide (5) or dicyanamide (6).

elements.content: 1 is a mononuclear complex, containing both coordinated and uncoordinated perchlorate ions. A similar geometrical arrangement around the copper(II) ion has been already described in other mononuclear dppn-based copper(II) complexes containing a chloride ion or a water molecule in the coordination sphere.
elements.clean_text: 1 is a mononuclear complex, containing both coordinated and uncoordinated perchlorate ions. A similar geometrical arrangement around the copper(II) ion has been already described in other mononuclear dppn-based copper(II) complexes containing a chloride ion or a water molecule in the coordination sphere.

elements.content: 2–4 are dinuclear compounds containing either mixed N–N/μ-OH (2) or double N–N (3 and 4) bridges. The [Cu2(dppn)(OH)]3+ dicopper(II) cationic fragment of 2 has been already observed in similar Cu(II) dinuclear compounds containing dppn and other ligands and most likely result from the metal hydrolysis during the synthesis.

elements.content: No copper(II) hydrolysis reaction takes place during the preparation of 3 and 4, where a 1:1 Cu(II)-dppn dimeric unit with two facially coordinated bridging dppn groups occurs. The occurrence of two facial bis-bidentate dppn molecules in 3 and 4 is very unusual and assumed not to be plausible in copper(II) complexes, where equatorial Cu–Ndppn bond distances are usually close to 2 Å, because of the sterical hindrance (see Chart ) between opposite pyridyl hydrogen atoms.

The occurrence of two facial bis-bidentate dppn molecules in 3 and 4 is very unusual and assumed not to be plausible in copper(II) complexes, where equatorial Cu-Ndppn bond distances are usually close to 2 Å, because of the sterical hindrance (see Chart ) between opposite pyridyl hydrogen atoms.

elements.content: This coordination geometry can be only found in a few literature silver(I) compounds containing 4-substituted dppn, where the more or less bulky substituent at the 4-position of the central pyridazine ring was noted to induce a considerable ligand distortion from planarity; moreover, the metal-Ndppn bond distances are about 2.3–2.4 Å in the case of Ag(I). Not surprisingly, the possibility to accommodate multiple dppn molecules has been documented, among others, in the presence of copper(I), with a quasi-orthogonal configuration of the ligands and the formation of a tetranuclear grid being favored by the typical tetrahedral geometry around the metal ion.

Not surprisingly, the possibility to accommodate multiple dppn molecules has been documented, among others, in the presence of copper(I), with a quasi-orthogonal configuration of the ligands and the formation of a tetranuclear grid being favored by the typical tetrahedral geometry around the metal ion.

elements.content: Evidently, the possibility to attain a double dppn-bridge, avoiding the expected geometric constraints between the pyridyl-hydrogen atoms, depends here on the flexibility of the metal coordination sphere, which indeed led to a butterfly conformation of the dimeric unit. Although the perchlorate ions act either as non- or weakly coordinating groups in 3 and 4 respectively, the differences between the bis(dppn)dicopper(II) units of the two complexes are minimal. This indicates that the perchlorate ion itself may only play a minor role in the formation of 3 and 4. Conversely, the occurrence of the double dppn-bridge in 3 and 4 can be instead attributed to or facilitated by the poor coordinating ability of the counterion that does not compete with the dppn ligand in the coordination to the copper center. Moreover, the anions participate in several anion-π type interactions with the aromatic ligand in both complexes. This fact may be essential for the ligand distortion required to stabilize such a geometry, thus explaining the lack of similar complexes featuring different counterions in the literature.

elements.content: In this respect, it seems worth mentioning that the importance of anion-π type interactions in self-assembly reactions and their decisive role in the determination of the observed structural motif were the subject of an early report by Dunbar et al. on silver(I) complexes of either dppn or the more π-acidic parent 3,6-bis(2′-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine (dptz).

elements.content: Given that 4 was observed in traces during the preparation of 3, and especially having in mind the minimal differences between the two cationic entities in both complexes, it is reasonable to assume that these two forms coexist in solution and that the solid state merely points out the possibility of replacing a water molecule by a perchlorate anion in the Cu(II) coordination sphere, without affecting the stability. Referring to Figures b and b, we can hypothesize that compound 4 generates out from 3 when the two coordinated water molecules are moved away from the coordination sphere of the copper(II) ion being substituted by noncoordinated perchlorate anions. The removal of the water molecules would result in the breaking of the supramolecular chain noted in 3 and the formation of neutral dicopper(II) units as noted in 4. Curiously, this reaction occurs in aqueous solution. We have no evidence of the reaction in the solid state, but it looks like compound 4 may be in principle obtained from 3 by gentle warming. This aspect remains to be further investigated. In conclusion, the coexistence of 3 and 4 in aqueous solution highlights the importance of the solvent and consequently of the hydrogen bonds, which surely play a very important role in the 3 ↔ 4 equilibrium.
elements.clean_text: Given that 4 was observed in traces during the preparation of 3, and especially having in mind the minimal differences between the two cationic entities in both complexes, it is reasonable to assume that these two forms coexist in solution and that the solid state merely points out the possibility of replacing a water molecule by a perchlorate anion in the Cu(II) coordination sphere, without affecting the stability. Referring to Figures b and b, we can hypothesize that compound 4 generates out from 3 when the two coordinated water molecules are moved away from the coordination sphere of the copper(II) ion being substituted by noncoordinated perchlorate anions. The removal of the water molecules would result in the breaking of the supramolecular chain noted in 3 and the formation of neutral dicopper(II) units as noted in 4. Curiously, this reaction occurs in aqueous solution. We have no evidence of the reaction in the solid state, but it looks like compound 4 may be in principle obtained from 3 by gentle warming. This aspect remains to be further investigated. In conclusion, the coexistence of 3 and 4 in aqueous solution highlights the importance of the solvent and consequently of the hydrogen bonds, which surely play a very important role in the 3 ↔ 4 equilibrium.

elements.content: Compounds 5 and 6 are somewhat uncommon as well. To the best of our knowledge, similar chain motifs have been previously observed only in dppn-containing copper(II) compounds with either bromide or tricyanomethanide (tcm) as coligands. Moreover, while compound 6 shows the common [Cu2(dppn)(OH)]3+ dicopper(II) cationic fragment, an unprecedent [Cu2(dppn)(N3)]3+ unit is present in 5.

elements.content: The water molecule of crystallization and one of the coordinated azide groups in 5 were both found to play a dual structural role. Indeed, two possible forms have been noted to coexist in the crystal structure of 5, noted 5A and 5B, as clarified in the descriptive section. 5B is constituted by dimeric units generating a supramolecular 1D motif along the crystallographic a axis. On the contrary, the dimeric units in 5A are covalently linked by μ-azide bridges. Consequently, the two forms essentially differ in the resulting dimensionality, and they are evidently structurally related. Indeed, 5A can be formed from 5B when water molecules are moved away from the coordination sphere of the copper(II) ion being replaced by the terminal azide ligands.

These values are very reduced with respect to that expected for two magnetically isolated spin doublets [χM T = 0.83 cm3 mol–1 K with g = 2.10] and they correspond practically to a complete spin paring situation caused by a very strong antiferromagnetic coupling (J ca. −1000 cm–1) between the copper(II) ions, the exchange pathways involved being the double pyridazine (3) and the combined single pyridazine/hydroxo bridges (2 and 6) plus a μ1,5-dca ligand (6).

Magnetic Properties

The values of χM T at room temperature for 2, 3 and 6 are in the range 0.012-015 cm3 mol-1 K [χM being the magnetic susceptibility per two copper(II) ions]. These values are very reduced with respect to that expected for two magnetically isolated spin doublets [χM T = 0.83 cm3 mol-1 K with g = 2.10] and they correspond practically to a complete spin paring situation caused by a very strong antiferromagnetic coupling (J ca. -1000 cm-1) between the copper(II) ions, the exchange pathways involved being the double pyridazine (3) and the combined single pyridazine/hydroxo bridges (2 and 6) plus a μ1,5-dca ligand (6).

elements.content:
The larger the value of S, the greater the antiferromagnetic coupling.

Looking at the structure of 3, the unpaired electron on each copper(II) ion (the so-called magnetic orbital) is described by a d(x 2–y 2) type orbital, the x and y axes being roughly defined by the equatorial copper to pyrazine-nitrogen bonds. A good overlap between these orbitals occurs through the two diazo bridges causing the strong antiferromagnetic coupling observed. In this respect, it deserves to be noted that the efficiency of the double diazine bridge to mediante magnetic interactions has been substantiated by previous magneto-structural studies on dicopper(II) complexes with double diatomic N–N or N–O bridges when the σ in-plane exchange pathway is operative, the singlet triplet energy gap attaining values as large as ca. 1000 cm–1.

elements.content: The single pyridazine and single hydroxo bridges connecting equatorial positions of the adjacent copper(II) ions in 2 are also well-known mediators of relatively large antiferromagnetic interactions in their copper(II) complexes. A good overlap between the magnetic orbitals of Cu(1) and Cu(2) in 2 (the unpaired electron on each copper atom is roughly localized in the equatorial plane) is at the origin of the antiferromagnetic coupling observed. An orientative value of the magnitude of the magnetic coupling 2 is provided by the compound {[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(tcm)2]·tcm} n (J = −1180 cm–1), both compounds having in common the combined single pyrazine/hydroxo skeleton linking two copper(II) ions. The orbital complementary effects between both bridges, a phenomenon that was treated for the first time by Nishida et al. and McKee et al., account for these giant antiferromagnetic couplings.

An orientative value of the magnitude of the magnetic coupling 2 is provided by the compound {[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(tcm)2]⋅tcm} n  (J = -1180 cm-1), both compounds having in common the combined single pyrazine/hydroxo skeleton linking two copper(II) ions. The orbital complementary effects between both bridges, a phenomenon that was treated for the first time by Nishida et al. and McKee et al., account for these giant antiferromagnetic couplings.

elements.content: Three possible exchange pathways occur in 6: (i) the combined single pyridazine/hydroxo bridge connecting equatorial positions (as in 2) and (ii) the single μ1,5-dca bridge linking one equatorial position of a copper(II) ion form a pyridazine/hydroxo-bridged dicopper(II) unit with an axial position of another copper(II) ion from a neighboring symmetry-related dicopper(II) unit. The low efficiency of the end to end dca bridge to mediate magnetic interactions between copper(II) ions, which has been demonstrated by previous magneto-structural studies, allow us to discard this exchange pathway and consider the other one as the responsible for the quasi diamagnetic character of 6. The fact that the values of the Cu(1)···Cu(2) separation and the angle at the bridgehead hydroxo in 6 [3.368(1) Å and 115.8(1)°, respectively] are very close to those in the related compound {[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(tcm)2]·tcm} n [3.363(8) Å and 125.0(2)°], reasonable supports a similar magnitude of the antiferromagnetic interaction in them.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of compound 5 in the form of both χM T and χM vs T plots [χM is the magnetic susceptibility per two copper(II) ions] are shown in Figure . χM T at 400 K is 0.28 cm3 mol–1 K, a value which is more reduced than that expected for two magnetically isolated spin doublets [χM T = 0.83 cm3 mol–1 K with g = 2.10]. This value decreases very fast upon cooling and it tends to vanish below 100 K. These features are indicative of the occurrence of a strong antiferromagnetic interaction between two copper(II) ions. The χM vs T plot shows the presence of a minimum at ca. 90 K and an abrupt increase at lower temperatures. The Curie law in the low temperature range for 5 was previously observed in dinuclear copper(II) complexes with a strong antiferromagnetic coupling, and it was attributed to the presence of a small fraction of paramagnetic impurities.

The best-fit parameters are J = −598(5) cm–1, g = 2.07(1), ρ = 0.050(2) and R = 1.1 × 10–5 (R is the agreement factor defined as ∑i[(χM)obs(i) – (χM)calc(i)]2/∑i[(χM)obs(i)]2). As shown in Figure , the calculated curve reproduces well the experimental data in the whole temperature range investigated.

elements.content: An inspection of the structure of 5 reveals the presence of three posible exchange pathways: (i) the combined single pyridazine/end-on azido bridge linking equatorial positions of Cu(1) and Cu(2); (ii) the double end-on azido connecting one equatorial position at one copper(II) ion with an axial one at another copper(II) ion; and (iii) the single end to end azido bridges connecting axial positions of copper(II) ions from symmetry-related dicopper(II) units. The magnetic orbitals describing the unpaired electron at each copper(II) ion in 5 are of the d(x 2–y 2) type the x and y axes being roughly defined by the copper to pyridazine-nitrogen and copper to end-on azido nitrogen bonds, respectively. The spin density remains thus in the respective equatorial plane and it will be very weak in the axial positions. This is the reason why the (ii) and (iii) exchange pathways can be discarded, the strong antiferromagnetic interaction observed in 5 being caused by the good overlap between the two magnetic orbitals through the (i) pathway. In this respect, strong antiferromagnetic magnetic interactions (values of J up to −900 cm–1) have been reported for dinuclear copper(II) complexes where the end-on azido and diazine (e.g., pyridazine, phthalazine) ligands act as bridges simultaneously, for copper–copper separations and angles at the azido bridge close that of 5 [3.469(1) Å and 122.3(1)°, respectively)]. The origin of the strong magnetic interactions observed in these systems is due to the complementary effects between the pyridazine and end-on azido, a phenomenon which was illustrated by some of us through MO calculations in a previous contribution.

elements.content: Six new copper(II)-dppn compounds have been synthesized and characterized. They show different structural architectures confirming the great versatility of this ligand in combination with copper(II) metal ion. While compounds 1 and 2 present the expected mononuclear (1) and dinuclear (2) molecular structure, featuring respectively two monochelated and a bis-chelated dppn ligands, compounds 3–6 show many interesting and unusual features.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Six new copper(II)-dppn compounds have been synthesized and characterized. They show different structural architectures confirming the great versatility of this ligand in combination with copper(II) metal ion. While compounds 1 and 2 present the expected mononuclear (1) and dinuclear (2) molecular structure, featuring respectively two monochelated and a bis-chelated dppn ligands, compounds 3-6 show many interesting and unusual features.

elements.content: In particular, the occurrence of compounds 3 and 4 is noteworthy. They contain a 1:1 Cu(II)-dppn dimeric unit with two facially coordinated bridging dppn groups, such arrangement of dppn molecules being never observed before in its copper(II) complexes. The poor coordinating ability of the counterion most likely contributes to the formation of the double dppn-bridge in 3 and 4. Moreover, the anion participates in several anion-π type interactions with the aromatic ligand in both complexes, assisting the ligand distortion required to stabilize such geometry. The minimal differences between the two cationic entities in both complexes suggest that these two forms coexist in solution and that compound 4 can generate out from 3 when the two coordinated water molecules are moved away from the coordination sphere of the copper(II) ion and are replaced by uncoordinated perchlorate anions.
elements.clean_text: In particular, the occurrence of compounds 3 and 4 is noteworthy. They contain a 1:1 Cu(II)-dppn dimeric unit with two facially coordinated bridging dppn groups, such arrangement of dppn molecules being never observed before in its copper(II) complexes. The poor coordinating ability of the counterion most likely contributes to the formation of the double dppn-bridge in 3 and 4. Moreover, the anion participates in several anion-π type interactions with the aromatic ligand in both complexes, assisting the ligand distortion required to stabilize such geometry. The minimal differences between the two cationic entities in both complexes suggest that these two forms coexist in solution and that compound 4 can generate out from 3 when the two coordinated water molecules are moved away from the coordination sphere of the copper(II) ion and are replaced by uncoordinated perchlorate anions.

elements.content: Concerning compounds 5 and 6, they are both 1D coordination polymers. To the best of our knowledge, only two other examples of 1D polymers based on dppn ligands have been reported in the literature to date. The occurrence of 5 and 6 definitely confirms the possibility of building 1D coordination polymers with bis-bidentate diazine ligands, even when the N2 diazine moiety is included in less flexible systems. Moreover, two different forms, referred to as 5A and 5B, coexist in the crystalline structure of 5, the first showing covalently azido-bridged dimeric units, and the second featuring discrete dimers containing monodentate azide and coordinated water molecules. As already pointed out in the case of 3 and 4, 5A can be derived from 5B when the coordinated water molecules in 5B are moved away from the coordination sphere of the metal ions being substituted by the terminal azide ligands.

elements.content: The unexpected outcomes of this research, coming from the study of evergreen metal ions and ligands such as Cu(II) and dppn, once more demonstrates that even if the basic principles of crystal engineering can be profitably applied to obtain specific coordination modes or supramolecular architectures, the control of the final structure and network topology still remain a challenge to be further explored and expanded.

cln_elements.content:
Caution! Perchlorate and azide salts are potentially explosive. Only small amounts of the materials should be prepared and handled with care.

[Cu(dppn)<sub>2</sub>(ClO<sub>4</sub>)]ClO<sub>4</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

This compound was obtained by reaction of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O and dppn in a 1:2 molar ratio. X-ray quality crystals of 1 as sky blue plates were obtained after a few days by slow diffusion in a test tube of an aqueous solution of the copper(II) salt into an ethanolic solution of the dppn ligand. The yield was practically quantitative. Anal. Calcd for C28H20Cl2CuN8O8 (1): C, 46.01; H, 2.76; N, 15.33. Found: C, 45.84; H, 2.68; N, 15.29%.

[Cu<sub>2</sub>(dppn)(OH)(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

X-ray quality crystals of 2 were obtained as green needles from a concentrated solution containing 0.2 mmol of the copper(II) salt dissolved in water and 0.1 mmol of dppn dissolved in ethanol. Yield: ca. 90%. Anal. Calcd for C14H19Cl3Cu2N4O17 (2): C, 22.46; H, 2.56; N, 7.48. Found: C, 22.30; H, 2.49; N, 7.36%.

[Cu<sub>2</sub>(dppn)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>](ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub> (<bold>3</bold>) and [Cu<sub>2</sub>(dppn)<sub>2</sub>(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub>] (<bold>4</bold>)

Compound 3 separated as a deep green crystalline solid by adding an aqueous solution of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol) to an ethanolic solution of the dppn ligand (0.1 mmol). Green rhombuses of 3 suitable for X-ray structural analysis were grown by slow diffusion in a H-shaped tube of the aqueous solution of the copper(II) salt in one arm and the ethanolic solution of the ligand in the other one. An ethanol/water mixture (1:1 v/v) was used to fill the H-tube. A few blue rhombuses of 4 appeared in the same tube after one month, when the diffusion was complete at room temperature. Crystals of 3 (main product) and 4 (traces) were collected together and separated manually. Yield of 3: ca. 55%. Anal. Calcd for C14H12Cl2CuN4O9 (3): C, 32.67; H, 2.35; N, 10.88. Found: C, 32.40; H, 2.40; N, 10.57%. The composition of 4 was established by crystallographic analysis.

{[Cu<sub>2</sub>(dppn)(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O/[Cu<sub>2</sub>(dppn)(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>) and {[Cu<sub>2</sub>(dppn)(OH)(dca)<sub>3</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O}<italic toggle="yes"> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>6</bold>)

Compounds 5 and 6 were both obtained as dark microcrystalline solids by reaction of Cu(ClO4)2 · 6H2O, dppn and NaN3 (5) or Na(dca) (6) in a 2:1:4 copper(II):dppn:N3/dca molar ratio. Single crystals as brown (5) or deep green (6) parallelepipeds were grown by slow diffusion in a H-shaped tube of an aqueous solution of the copper(II) salt in one arm and an ethanolic solution containing a mixture of dppn and azide (5) or dicyanamide (6) salts in the other one. An ethanol/water mixture (1:1 v/v) was used to fill the H-tube. The diffusion was completed after one month. Yield: ca. 65 (5) and 70% (6). Anal. Calcd for C14H12Cu2N16O (5): C, 30.71; H, 2.21; N, 40.93. Found: C, 30.16; H, 2.18; N, 41.12%. Anal. Calcd for C20H13Cu2N13O2 (6): C, 40.40; H, 2.20; N, 30.63. Found: C, 39.89; H, 2.16; N, 30.23%.

Green rhombuses of 3 suitable for X-ray structural analysis were grown by slow diffusion in a H-shaped tube of the aqueous solution of the copper(II) salt in one arm and the ethanolic solution of the ligand in the other one. An ethanol/water mixture (1:1 v/v) was used to fill the H-tube. A few blue rhombuses of 4 appeared in the same tube after one month, when the diffusion was complete at room temperature. Crystals of 3 (main product) and 4 (traces) were collected together and separated manually. Yield of 3: ca. 55%. Anal. Calcd for C14H12Cl2CuN4O9 (3): C, 32.67; H, 2.35; N, 10.88. Found: C, 32.40; H, 2.40; N, 10.57%. The composition of 4 was established by crystallographic analysis.

{[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4]⋅H2O/[Cu2(dppn)(N3)4(H2O)]} n  (5) and {[Cu2(dppn)(OH)(dca)3]⋅H2O} n  (6)

Compounds 5 and 6 were both obtained as dark microcrystalline solids by reaction of Cu(ClO4)2 ⋅ 6H2O, dppn and NaN3 (5) or Na(dca) (6) in a 2:1:4 copper(II):dppn:N3/dca molar ratio. Single crystals as brown (5) or deep green (6) parallelepipeds were grown by slow diffusion in a H-shaped tube of an aqueous solution of the copper(II) salt in one arm and an ethanolic solution containing a mixture of dppn and azide (5) or dicyanamide (6) salts in the other one. An ethanol/water mixture (1:1 v/v) was used to fill the H-tube. The diffusion was completed after one month. Yield: ca. 65 (5) and 70% (6). Anal. Calcd for C14H12Cu2N16O (5): C, 30.71; H, 2.21; N, 40.93. Found: C, 30.16; H, 2.18; N, 41.12%. Anal. Calcd for C20H13Cu2N13O2 (6): C, 40.40; H, 2.20; N, 30.63. Found: C, 39.89; H, 2.16; N, 30.23%.

cln_elements.content: The magnetic properties of compound 5 in the form of both χM T and χM vs T plots [χM is the magnetic susceptibility per two copper(II) ions] are shown in Figure . χM T at 400 K is 0.28 cm3 mol–1 K, a value which is more reduced than that expected for two magnetically isolated spin doublets [χM T = 0.83 cm3 mol–1 K with g = 2.10]. This value decreases very fast upon cooling and it tends to vanish below 100 K. These features are indicative of the occurrence of a strong antiferromagnetic interaction between two copper(II) ions. The χM vs T plot shows the presence of a minimum at ca. 90 K and an abrupt increase at lower temperatures. The Curie law in the low temperature range for 5 was previously observed in dinuclear copper(II) complexes with a strong antiferromagnetic coupling, and it was attributed to the presence of a small fraction of paramagnetic impurities.
